The study of load consumption patterns through subsequence mining is a crucial task in smart cities and buildings as it extracts knowledge to assist in energy planning and management. The existing clustering based solutions do not capture the temporal dependency between the subsequences. Clustering temporally dependent similar subsequences can uncover key insight in a wide range of applications including demand response programs. In this work, we formulate the subsequence clustering on residential building load data as a graph clustering problem on a weighted directed graph. The weighted directed graph structure helps to capture the temporal dependency as well as the similarity between the subsequences. We propose a novel quasi-clique based graph clustering algorithm. No prior information about the number of clusters is required. The comparative study performed on residential building load dataset shows more than 15% improvement over the existing methods. The qualitative analysis of the distinctive patterns obtained from cluster centroids justifies a meaningful cluster set discovery. The labeled subsequences obtained through clustering helps to identify the successively occurring and atypical patterns, measure the stability of consumers that can rank the consumers for their suitability in demand response programs (DR) and load shifting operations. Keywords Time series subsequence Demand response Residential buildings Graph clustering Symbolic representation 1 Introduction To control the environmental hazards caused due to the combustion of fossil fuels at the facilities for energy [1,2], the renewable energy sources (REs) that utilize the forces of nature - wind, sun and seas in particular are growing their share in electricity generation [3,4]. The contribution of REs to the total generated electricity is projected to increase to almost 30% in 2021. 1 1 https://www.iea.org. While a higher penetration of renewable are encouraged in the power system, the additional challenges imposed include: the supply-side variability and uncertainty of the renewable energy sources; balancing supply and demand relationship during generation scarcity and surplus situations. To mitigate these challenges, in addition to the existing solutions of using the flexible renewable generation source [5] and storage [6], a variety of new solutions need to be developed to create a smart energy system (SES) that is fuel-efficient, economically and environmentally feasible. Particularly, as the energy consumption of buildings account for nearly one third of the global energy usage, controlling the building modus operandi can significantly contribute in developing an efficient eco-friendly SES. Further, the smart buildings, possibly equipped with onsite REs, have the potential to mitigate the challenge of balancing supply and demand relationship by participating in the demand response programs [7]. With the installation of the advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) along with the measurement technologies like smart meters in the residential buildings, it has been possible to accumulate a massive amount of load data that now offer the opportunity to understand how different residential building load patterns can be utilized to tackle various problems of future power system operation [8]. The common data mining and analysis problems that are well studied in this context include: load forecasting [9–11], clustering electricity load profiles [11,12], building energy benchmarking [13], electrical equipment identification [14], domain specific knowledge extraction [15]; temporal pattern discovery [16,17], motif and discord discovery [18]. The problem of analysis of load profiles to identify the consumers suitable for adopting demand response (DR) program received limited attention from the research community. In this paper we aim to identify the buildings that have the potential to undergo DR programs persistently for longer periods, primarily through peak load shifting and through reduction in daily energy consumption by adopting behavioral changes. In this paper, the term building refer to the residential households. The assumption here is that the buildings which show persistent load patterns through long term contractual agreement are likely to adjust their behavior pattern resulting in consistent peak load shifting and reduced daily energy consumption. Such buildings are considered as stable. The buildings with stable consumption patterns can help utility providers to better plan and manage the power generation capacity. The stable buildings that agree to participate in DR programs may be offered with price incentives or flexible pricing schemes. Exploiting the fact that small subsequences can capture the regularity in patterns from the historic load data of individual buildings, this paper address the problem using time series subsequence clustering that can segregate the stable building set from the unstable ones. In Table 1 we present a summary of the relevant studies that apply clustering based approaches for DSM or DR applications. As highlighted in Table 1, the existing clustering based solutions cannot be applied for this study as they only consider shape based or the feature based similarity between the subsequences but ignore the complex temporal dependency between subsequences. Moreover, the pairwise similarity computation method used in subsequence clustering [25,26] is not scalable for large time series datasets. Motivated by the success of graph theoretic approaches in extracting dependent events, we propose a graph based approach to cluster the temporally dependent similar subsequences. In this work, we formulate the subsequence clustering on time series dataset problem as a dense subgraph mining problem from weighted directed graph. The novelty of the proposed weighted directed graph is that it can capture the temporal dependency between the subsequences using directed edges and the similarity between the subsequences using the edge weights. The dense sub-graphs from the weighted directed graph is defined using the concepts of quasi-clique. A quasi-clique based graph clustering approach can help identify the typical as well as the atypical patterns. Further labeled subsequences obtained through dense subgraph mining are used to measure the stability of consumers. Our key contributions in this paper are highlighted in Fig. 1 and discussed below. 1. Dimension reduction using a new SAX based approach: the time series representing load data are segmented into non-overlapping time series subsequences and encoded using a modified SAX based approach for dimensionality reduction, 2. A novel graph representation for time series data: the symbolic representation of the non-overlapping time series subsequences are used to construct a graph structure that can capture the temporal dependency between the subsequences using directed edges and the similarity between the subsequences using the edge weights, 3. A novel graph clustering algorithm: a quasi-clique based novel graph clustering algorithm is developed for identifying the cohesive subgraphs that uncovers the successively occurring most similar patterns, 4. New graph based pattern analysis: cluster signatures and successive occurrences of similar consumption patterns are identified for load profiling and successively the atypical consumption patterns from the graph representation of time series dataset are extracted, 5. An entropy based index to rank stable consumers: an entropy based measure is used to identify the set of buildings with stable consumption pattern. Successively for given time interval, the stable consumers showing their peak consumption are identified for load shifting. The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 the related work on subsequence clustering and its applications are discussed. Section 3 illustrates the proposed framework and the applications. Sections 5 and 6 elaborates the experiment setup and the results successively. In Section 7 the conclusions and future work is discussed. 2 Literature Subsequence mining for the analysis of building energy data has unveiled many key insights. In spite of some contradictory opinions [27], unsupervised clustering is proved to be a popular subsequence mining technique that groups the subsequences based on their similarity. According to Chen et al. [28], clustering of subsequences depends on two factors, first is how clusters are formed by the clustering method and second is how the cluster center, that is, the representative of cluster is chosen. Ignoring some of the subsequence or choosing only the clusterable subsequences [29] can give better cluster results. Other important factors to obtain meaningful subsequence cluster depends on window length and the distance measures used. Das et al. [30] used a mapping from the time series to a discrete representation before applying K-means clustering. The method however has limited applications as the cluster centroids formed are sinusoidal waveforms that are unrelated to the actual patterns of the time series. Following his work, several solutions to the problem have been proposed. For example, Rodpongpun et al. [31] proposed a data encoding technique that can extract the important subsequences and ignore the rest. They have used variable length windows and the number of clusters are decided automatically but no description about the choice of alphabets for symbolic representation is given. The subsequence clustering has been successfully used for rule discovery [30] and motif and discord discovery from the time series. Rule discovery is extraction of the causal events that have multiple occurrences during a time frame. Motifs are the frequently occurring patterns in the data which are discovered by mining all the possible subsequences of time series [32] while discords are the rare event patterns observed in the data [33]. In [34], the authors use K-medoid algorithm to cluster the discovered motifs. The sliding window approach is used to obtain all possible subsequences, with the trivially matching subsequences removed before clustering the motifs. The most suitable clusters are obtained by varying the window size and SAX alphabet sizes. Similarity search is a computational bottleneck for time series data mining algorithms, including clustering and motif discovery on large data set. The early abandoning techniques of dynamic time warping (DTW), Euclidean distance are one of the approaches to reduce the computational burden [35]. Another approach is to convert the time series to a dimensionally reduced representation [22,36] before clustering. The techniques like wavelet based transforms in [37,38], principal components [39], hidden Markov models [40], model based feature learning [41], are used to obtain a compressed data representation. Since time series is a continuous real valued data, the characteristics of the patterns change with time. There are several discriminative properties in time series which helps in clustering and motif discovery techniques and the dimensionality reduction approaches should retain such properties. The piecewise aggregate approximation (PAA) method is a promising dimensionality reduction approach, in which the time series is discretized into segments and converted to a symbolic data [42]. The clustering and motif detection techniques from the symbolic data representation in [43–45] have shown promising results. In this paper, the dimensionally reduced time series is combined with the graph based structure. There are some properties in graph based structure, that assists in capturing the time series pattern 1. the vertices can be used to represent the unique patterns from time series 2. the weighted edges can be used to represent the similarity between paired vertices 3. the directionality of the edges can help in preserving the temporally dependent events in time series. Time series data to a graph based representation is shown in [33] for anomaly discovery, in [46] for whole time series clustering, in [47] for rule discovery. Several subsequence time series (STS) clustering approaches in literature have used the pairwise similarity measure and achieved good results [48–50]. However, none of them discuss about extracting the temporal information from the time series to be used for STS clustering. The unweighted undirected graph clustering is faster and abundant in literature as compared to the weighted and directed graphs. There are some approaches, discussed in [51] to convert the directed graph into undirected and then apply the traditional community detection algorithms, but this conversion in case of time series will cause loss of temporal information. The STS clustering on symbolic time series, from the weighted directed graph based network is an informative tool that can be utilized for DR programs. Consumers participating in DR programs are rewarded with several incentives [52] and the rewards are based on the type of DR programs they participated in: the price based DR programs or the incentive based DR programs. In case of price based programs, the consumers are provided with the cost of electricity usage during different times of the day and in the incentive based DR programs, the utilities can directly control various appliances owned by the consumer [53]. The purpose of both the programs is to curtail the electricity usage during peak period to avoid power outage. Yilmaz et al. [54] perform a cluster analysis and identify the buildings’ start of peak and peak intensity, to help in DR programs. In [22] the authors apply hierarchical clustering on the subsequences extracted from daily load consumption (DLC) of the buildings. Load profile of electrical appliances like heater [23] and air-conditioners [24] and other wet appliances [55] is shown to be effective in planning for load shifting operations. In [20] the authors obtain cluster representatives for each season and draw a correlation of the discovered cluster membership with the existing survey data of the households. The above studies however do not specify how and which of the buildings are suitable for DSM applications during a certain time. In spite of this challenge involved in DSM, it has received limited attention from the scientific community. 3 Methodology In this section, we discuss motivation behind the proposed work and the details of the proposed clustering approach. 3.1 Motivation The subsequence clustering from a massive time series dataset is a challenging task. Existing clustering approaches look for similarity between the subsequences but they do not consider the temporal dependency between the subsequences. The graph theoretic approaches have been successful in mining similar as well as dependent events across several applications. To the best of the authors knowledge, no graph theoretic approach has been used to cluster the temporally dependent similar subsequences. In this work, we formulate the subsequence clustering on time series dataset problem as a dense subgraph mining problem from weighted directed graph where the time series dataset is represented as a weighted directed graph with the directed edges preserving the temporal dependency between subsequences and the edge weights representing the similarity between subsequences. Clustering temporal dependent similar subsequences has wide area of applications towards identifying the causal consumption patterns. For example, the appliance usages at the same time or the consecutive appliance usages in the residential buildings, the frequently occurring significant events and also in the demand response (DR) applications. Out of the many possible application areas, in this paper, we discuss some of the DR applications like- identifying the buildings with stable consumption patterns. For stable building identification, the assumption is the buildings that follow consistent load patterns, are more likely to adjust their behavior pattern resulting in persistent peak load shifting and reduced daily energy consumption through long term contractual agreement. For atypical pattern identification, a subsequence that is followed by minimum number of other unique patterns is considered atypical. A flowchart describing the control flow between different steps of the proposed framework is briefly described using Fig. 2. The input to the flowchart is the load time series data for a set of buildings, denoted as T = { t 1 … t m } , each measuring load for n different instances. The data pre processing steps for missing data imputation, duplicate removal and normalization are discussed in Section 5.1. The first important step is segmentation and symbolic representation on T which is discussed in Section 3.3. The symbolic data is used for graph representation as discussed in Section 3.4. The details of the proposed quasi clique clustering technique on the graph is discussed in Section 3.5. The cluster labels thus obtained ( S G ) is finally used for DR programs as discussed in Section 4. 3.2 Definitions and notations To describe the proposed framework we discuss the notations and define the underlying concepts. Notation 1 Time Series Dataset The time series dataset is denoted by a matrix, T = R m × n , where, m is the number of time series samples and | t i | = n , ∀ t i ∈ T . Notation 2 Time Series Subsequences A time series t i , is split into equal length non-overlapping segments, called the subsequences of length l . Given the time series t i , the subsequence of t i starting at time instance j is { t i j … t i ( j + l − 1 ) } . Notation 3 Graph A directed weighted graph is denoted as G ( V , E , W ) , where V is the set of vertices, E is the set of directed weighted edges and W ( e i , j ) is the weight function that maps an edge e i , j ∈ E to a real value. Notation 4 Vertex Weight Weight of a vertex v i ∈ V is the sum of weights of its outgoing edges given as: W ( v i ) ← s u m j ( W ( e i , j ) ) , where e i , j ∈ E is an outgoing edge from v i to v j ∈ V . Definition 1 Maximum Clique on a Weighted Graph Given a weighted graph, a clique is defined as a complete subgraph s such that for every pair of vertices i , j ∈ s there exists an edge ( i , j ) in s and the summation of the edge weights of s is the maximum over all complete subgraphs in G . Definition 2 Clique on a Directed Graph Given a directed graph, a clique is defined as a subgraph s such that for every pair of vertices i , j ∈ s there exists both the edges i → j and j → i . Definition 3 γ -quasi-clique Given a unweighted undirected graph, a γ -quasi-clique is defined as a subgraph s if ∀ i ∈ s , d e g ( i ) ( | s | − 1 ) ≥ γ , where 0 ≤ γ ≤ 1 . 3.3 Segmentation and symbolic representation As mentioned in Notation 2, the segmentation process splits a time series into equal length non-overlapping subsequences. Two subsequences, t i x and t i y are non-overlapping if y ≥ x + l − 1 , where x and y are the start times of the respective subsequences. The number of subsequences, for each t i of length n is q = n / l , where l is the length of the subsequences. Determination of the value of l is important for the analysis of subsequences: a very high value of l may result in loss of information while a very small value of l may produce many unique encodings that might fail to find the common patterns between the subsequences. After the segmentation of ∀ t i ∈ T , each subsequence is encoded using a symbolic representation. Symbolic representation of a subsequence is a dimensionality reduction approach where a sequence of real valued data is mapped to a set of symbols. Following the extended SAX approach developed in [56], to capture information about the trend and peaks of a subsequence t i j , the three features used to represent each subsequence are: 1. the average or mean value, given as μ ( t i j ) 2. the slope value, that captures the trend of the subsequence, given as s l o p e ( t i j ) 3. difference between the maximum and minimum value, that determines the range of values in the subsequence, given as, d i f ( t i j ) . Though other features may be considered instead of the above mentioned set of the features, the selected feature set can be computed in linear time that is important for analysis of large datasets. We use Symbolic aggregate approximation (SAX) [42] based discretization approach to convert the features into symbols. Let the Piecewise Aggregate Approximation (PAA) of the normalized time series t i be t ̄ i . For a given alphabet a > 2 , the sorted list of breakpoints B a = { β k } k = 1 a − 1 , is used to obtain the SAX symbols using Eq. (1), (1) t ̃ i j = α k , if β k − 1 ≤ t ̄ i j ≤ β k where j ∈ { 1 , … , q } and α k denote the k th element of the alphabet. The pseudo code for symbolic representation is discussed in algorithm 1. F f × m × q is a tensor, where f denotes the number of features that represent a subsequence. We assume a vector of alphabet sizes a = { 3 , … , 20 } , from which the appropriate alphabet size is obtained for each feature. To obtain the appropriate alphabet size for each feature { F x } x = 1 f , we compute the median value. For example, in case of mean represented as F 1 , we compute median( F 1 × m × q ). In step 9 of algorithm 1, m e d is a vector which stores the median value of the features and E is the vector which stores the minimum value of | B a − m e d [ f ] | . For the feature f , we obtain the alphabet size α [ f ] whose corresponding breakpoint is closest to the median value of the feature f , as shown in step 14. The maximum from vector α , that is, α o p t is chosen for symbolic representation of entire time series. Output of algorithm 1 is the symbolic representation of the original time series data set T , given as T ̃ m × q . 3.4 Graph representation The symbolically represented time series data T ̃ is modeled as a directed weighted graph G as denoted in Notation 3. As the aim is to extract the groups of similar subsequences occurring in the time series data set, we propose the following approach for construction of graph that preserve the temporal order of occurrence of the subsequences. The subsequences with same symbols represent similar patterns, therefore we extract the unique symbols in T ̃ that form the graph vertices. Mapping of a unique symbol to a vertex of G is given by the mapping function V : t i ̃ j → v i . Relaxing the existing definition of clique on a weighted graph 1 and on a directed graph 2 and extending the definition of a γ -quasi clique on a weighted graph 3, we propose the definition of ψ -quasi clique on a directed weighted graph with normalized edge weight. Definition 4 Given a weighted directed graph G , a subgraph s is called a ψ -quasi clique if both the following conditions are satisfied 1. s is a weakly connected component (WCCs), and 2. if ∀ i ∈ s , m i n ( w ( i ) , d e g − ( i ) ) | s | − 1 ≥ ψ , where 0 ≤ ψ ≤ 1 and d e g − ( i ) is the out-degree of vertex i . The first condition ensures that the temporal order of occurrence of patterns represented by the vertices is preserved while the second condition ensures that every γ -quasi clique is dense even for a disassortative graph where vertex weight and vertex degree are not correlated. A clique on a weighted directed graph with normalized edge weights is a special ψ -quasi-clique where every pair of vertices form a SCC that is for every pair of vertices ( i , j ) there exist both the directed edge i → j and i ← j and ψ = 1 . We further propose the definition of a maximal ψ -quasi clique on a directed weighted graph with normalized edge weight as below: Definition 5 Given a weighted directed graph G , a subgraph s is called a maximal ψ -quasi-clique if all the following conditions are satisfied - 1. s is a ψ -quasi clique on G , where 0 ≤ ψ ≤ 1 , and 2. for all i ∈ V such that i is a neighbor to s , s ∪ { i } seize to remain a ψ -quasi clique on G . The complexity of the naive problem of finding all the maximal ψ -quasi cliques from a given weighted directed graph G is exponential in the size of the input graph. It is known that there can be as much as Ω ( 3 n / 3 ) maximal cliques in a graph [57], and hence there can be at least as many maximal quasi-cliques, since each clique is a special ψ -quasi clique. Even it is shown that it is computationally hard to propose an approximation algorithm for this problem [58]. In this work we propose a bottom up greedy graph clustering algorithm such that every cluster is the maximal ψ -quasi clique in the given weighted directed graph G as mentioned in algorithm 2. The vertices are first arranged in non-increasing order of their weight values W ( v i ) in the priority queue Q where the priority is the weight value of the vertices W ( v i ) . Vertex with highest weight act as the central vertex of G because it is either connected to maximum number of other vertices of the graph or it is connected to other vertices which are most similar to it. The greedy strategy used in the algorithm is that inclusion of the vertex with higher weight to the cluster at an early stage, helps to find the maximal ψ -quasi clique as compared to the strategy of including a vertex with lower weight. The term clusters and subgraphs S G are interchangeably used in the algorithm 2. Initially, the vertex with highest weight forms an individual cluster { s i } . At each iteration, the vertex with next highest weight that is also neighbor of s i is chosen as s j . The subgraphs s i and s j are merged if the following conditions are satisfied - 1. the new subgraph, n e w _ s i should form a WCC, that ensures a minimum connectivity between the vertices. The WCC are found by a breadth-first search algorithm. 2. the new subgraph, n e w _ s i should satisfy the condition ψ ( n e w _ s i ) ≥ ψ m i n , where, (5) ψ ( n e w _ s i ) = min ∀ v ∈ n e w _ s i min ( W ( v ) , d e g − ( v ) ) ( z − 1 ) where, z = | n e w _ s i | , the number of vertices in subgraph n e w _ s i . The parameter ψ m i n determines the quality of the clusters. The iterations are repeated until no more merge is possible with s i . s i forms a maximal ψ -quasi clique. The above steps are repeated for all the vertices that do not belong to s i . The algorithm returns a set of subgraph S G which are the maximal ψ -quasi cliques of graph G . 3.6 Working example An example of the segmentation, symbolic representation, graph formation and clustering in shown in Fig. 3. Time for obtaining a segment from a time series is O ( 1 ) . For time series t i , the number of subsequences obtained is q = n / l . The time complexity for feature extraction from a subsequence of length l is O ( l ) . For the dataset with m time series samples each of length n , the worst case complexity for segmentation is O ( m n ) . In case n ≫ m , the time complexity becomes, O ( n ) . The symbolic representation require to compute the median value of features. For total m × n / l number of subsequences and n ≫ m , the time complexity for median value computation in worst case is O ( n × log n ) . Time to obtain α o p t for the symbolic representation is O ( 1 ) . The symbolic representation is linearly dependent on number of features. For f different features, the worst case time complexity is O ( m × ( n / l ) × f ) , and n ≫ m , it becomes O ( n ) . Therefore the worst case complexity for symbolic representation is max ( O ( n log n ) , O ( n ) ) = O ( n log n ) . In the worst case, the total number of unique symbols extracted as graph vertices is approximately m × ( n / l ) , therefore the time complexity to extract the unique symbols is O ( m × ( n l log n l ) ) and as n ≫ m , it becomes O ( n log n ) . Deciding the edge direction is based on sorting the subsequences in time order, which also require O ( n log n ) time. For f features, the time complexity to compute the edge weight using modified SAX distance is O ( f 2 ) . In worst case, if we consider a complete graph with m × ( n / l ) number of vertices, the worst case time complexity for edge weight computation is when n ≫ m is, O ( n 2 ) . Therefore, the time complexity for graph representation is max ( O ( n ) , O ( n log n ) , O ( n 2 ) ) = O ( n 2 ) . Considering the directed weighted graph G ( V , E , W ) , the quasi-clique based clustering approach has three main steps- 1. Sorting vertices on vertex weights. The time complexity is O ( V log V ) . 2. Two conditions are checked before each merge, as given in Section 3.5. The time complexity to obtain WCC is O ( V + E ) and the time to check whether ψ -quasi clique satisfies, is constant. In worst case, a merge occurs in each step, the time complexity becomes O ( V × ( V + E ) ) . In worst case, the maximum number of vertices in G is approximately m × n / l . For n ≫ m , the total time complexity for the proposed quasi clique clustering approach is O ( n 2 ) . 4 Application to DR programs We discuss two application areas where the labeled subsequences can help in achieving energy efficiency through demand response program. Firstly, we find a stable set of buildings which are suitable for the load shifting operations. Secondly, we identify the atypical patterns using graph degree analysis. 4.1 Measuring stability The buildings that follow consistent load patterns, are considered as stable customers that are suitable for the DR as well as energy efficient (EE) programs [59,60] focusing peak load shifting and peak as well as daily consumption reduction. The buildings showing sudden change in consumption patterns are less likely to meet the said objectives as sudden consumption change indicates the presence of uncertain factors that trigger the unpredictable load pattern. Assuming a cluster set S G = { s i } i = 1 C , we use the information theory metric Shannon’s entropy to measure the stability score of a building ( t j ) that can be computed as [61]: (6) H ( t j ) = − ∑ i = 1 C S ( s i , t j ) × log S ( s i , t j ) where the temporal variation function S ( . ) intends to find the membership of the cluster label s i in the building t j . The temporal variation function is defined as: S ( s i , t j ) = 1 q ∑ p = 1 q δ ( s i , t j p ) , where δ ( s i , t j p ) = 1 , if the cluster label for the subsequence t j p is s i and 0 otherwise. q is the total number of subsequences. The buildings showing lesser H ( . ) value are considered to have high stability score and are likely to have more consistent demand. If they are selected for DR programs, they will result in persistent participation to DR programs for longer period of time. We compute the entropy of t 1 , t 2 and t 3 based on the cluster labels obtained, illustrated in Fig. 3(g). In t 3 all the segments belong to cluster 2 and in t 2 , cluster label 2 is observed in three consecutive subsequences. t 1 has four different cluster labels. The entropy for t 3 is − [ 4 4 × log ( 4 4 ) ] = 0 . The entropy for t 2 is − [ 1 4 × log ( 1 4 ) + 3 4 × log ( 3 4 ) ] = 0 . 56 and entropy for t 1 is − [ 1 4 × log ( 1 4 ) + 1 4 × log ( 1 4 ) + 1 4 × log ( 1 4 ) + 1 4 × log ( 1 4 ) ] = 1 . 38 . Therefore, as per the entropy measure, t 3 is most stable and t 1 is the most unstable. 4.2 Peak detection Through the DR programs the utilities aim to shift certain loads to off peak time thereby reducing the peak load. In this context, we show how and which buildings should be chosen for the load shifting. The steps are discussed below: 1. We assume a time interval [ p , q ] as the peak hour for load shifting. In case of residential buildings, generally the evening hours are considered as busiest hours of the day and so in our experiments, we choose [ p , q ] as the evening hours for analyses. 2. We rank the buildings based on the non-decreasing value of the stability measure discussed in Section 4.1. The top- k buildings denoted by a set SB are extracted based on the rank order such that: building t i ∈ S B if arg max { t i x } ∈ [ p , q ] , where t i x is the subsequence of the building t i . The top- k signify the buildings with lowest entropy or the high stability score. The choice of k depends on how many buildings from the stable set, do the utilities require so that the peak is reduced during DR time interval. 4.3 Atypical pattern identification The consumption patterns which are different from the majority and are irregular in nature, are regarded as atypical patterns. Identification of the irregular patterns assist the utilities in decision making process and also in designing accurate load prediction models. The atypical patterns need special attention as they could occur due to faulty devices, leakage or simply because of exceptional usage pattern. It has been a tradition to identify the atypical patterns by using the brute force method, but when it comes to large time series datasets, the method becomes computationally expensive. We propose a graph based analytical approach to discover the unique patterns from the entire time series dataset. The key to identify the atypical pattern is to examine the frequency of occurrence of the symbol and the degree of the vertex in graph G . It is observed that the vertices with lower degrees have minimal frequency of occurrence in the time series dataset. Degree of the vertex capture the number of temporally dependent unique patterns. The vertex with fewer degrees has only a few temporally dependent patterns while a higher degree vertex signify that it has many temporally dependent patterns. As a consequence, we isolate the lower degree vertices based on the threshold value v d and the representative patterns of the isolated vertices are considered as the atypical patterns. The value of v d is decided on the basis of degree distribution of the vertices. 5 Experiments In this section we discuss about the datasets used, the experimental design, the evaluation measures used for the comparative analysis of clustering results obtained from proposed quasi clique technique and the baseline methods. 5.1 Data description Two residential buildings dataset are used in our experimental study- London household data [62] and Ausgrid solar homes electricity data [63]. The London households energy dataset consist of half hourly power readings of 210 buildings, each of which belong to one of the three categories. The dataset belongs to a project named “Low Carbon London” led by UK power networks. The three categories of buildings used in the dataset are- adversity, affluent and comfortable. The affluent category customers have executive wealth and lavish lifestyles, the adversity category have young families with low cost flats or poor families with too many children, the comfortable category customers have farms and cottages or larger families in rural areas. More information about the category types is available with the data set. 2 2 https://acorn.caci.co.uk/what-is-acorn. Ausgrid solar home dataset, consist of gross meter readings for 300 customers in Ausgrid area. The homes have solar system installed at their rooftops. Dataset contains half hourly load consumption values over an year. Both the datasets show individual building energy consumption, which is suitable for our analyses. The chosen datasets are publicly available for study and analyses. The data pre-processing part include– missing value removal, duplicate removal and normalization. Linear interpolation is used in the London households dataset to impute the missing values. The Ausgrid electricity data do not have missing values but it has duplicates which is replaced by the mean values. The real valued half-hourly data are z-score normalized before performing the experiments. 5.2 Experimental design 1. Parameter sensitivity: We first carry out the parameter sensitivity test to identify the best parameter configuration of the proposed method. The subsequence length (WL) and ψ are the two graph parameters in the proposed graph representation. Total number of subsequences in a time series is inversely proportional to the subsequence length. Very long subsequence can cause information loss and very short length subsequences might fail to capture the common patterns leading to large number of clusters. To obtain the best WL (WL = 2 l ), we vary it as- 1,2,4,6,8,12 and 24 h. ψ regulates the edge density of a subgraph and its value ranges from 0 to 1 . The edge weights are normalized from 0 to 1 , where 0 signifies no similarity between the corresponding vertex pair and 1 signifies maximum similarity. Greater the value of ψ , more similar are the vertices of subgraph. 2. Planted quasi clique: To evaluate the reliability of the proposed quasi clique clustering technique, we test if the proposed clustering technique can detect the manually implanted maximal quasi cliques. The vertices of a subgraph formed by manually implanted maximal quasi cliques are assigned to a single cluster and are assumed as true labels and the labels obtained from proposed quasi clique clustering technique are assumed as predicted labels. The experiments are evaluated using the normalized mutual information (NMI) between the actual and the predicted labels, discussed in Section 5.3. 3. Cluster quality: We apply the proposed quasi-clique clustering algorithm on the directed weighted graph obtained from each WL and determine the best cluster set using the cluster quality measures. At this stage, we compare the cluster quality obtained from the proposed clustering technique with the existing state-of-the-art methods. The cluster quality measures used for comparison with the state-of-the-art methods are: Davies Bouldin (DB) and Edge Density (ED) which is discussed in Section 5.3. The state-of-the-art clustering techniques is discussed in Section 5.4. Statistical test: The Friedman test is carried out to check whether the proposed method or any of the state-of-art clustering technique perform better than others or not. As each clustering method is evaluated on multiple WL, the Friedman test is suitable for comparisons across multiple state-of-the-art clustering methods. The rejection of null-hypothesis in Friedman test signify that the cluster quality results obtained from all the clustering methods are not same. On rejection of null hypothesis of Friedman test, the post hoc Nemenyi test [64] is carried out that is useful for pairwise comparison of the proposed quasi clique clustering technique with the existing state-of-the art clustering. 4. Cluster characterization: The cluster characterization is performed on the cluster labels obtained from the best graph representation, decided on the cluster quality measures: DB index and ED, as discussed in Section 5.3. Firstly we categorize the clusters based on the similarity in their shapes. Cluster centroid of each cluster is studied, which is the mean of load data values of the cluster samples. Secondly, we analyze the time of occurrences of the patterns, identified by the cluster shapes, using the heat map. Finally we obtain the consecutively occurring patterns in the time series that belong to same cluster. 5. Application to DR programs: The DR program based applications discussed in Section 4 are performed on the best graph representation obtained using the cluster quality measures DB and ED for each dataset. The validity of the DR applications is shown on a real life time series dataset with labeled DSM information. We show how much the predicted stable set of buildings match with the actual labels in terms of accuracy, discussed in Section 5.3. In case of atypical pattern identification, the Wilcoxon signed rank test is performed to check if there exists significant difference in the frequency of occurrence of the atypical patterns with that of the normal patterns. The number of atypical patterns in the time series dataset is significantly lower than the normal patterns and therefore Wilcoxon signed rank test is considered suitable for the lower number of samples. We randomly choose the samples from the frequency of occurrence of the normal patterns and pair with frequency of occurrence of the atypical patterns, to perform the Wilcoxon signed rank test. 5.3 Evaluation metrics Below we discuss the evaluation metrics and the statistical tests used in the experiments. Normalized mutual information (NMI): This is the measure of normalized mutual dependencies between the ground truth information ( A ) and the predicted information ( P ), computed as (7) N M I ( A , P ) = 2 × I ( A , P ) H ( A ) + H ( P ) where, H ( . ) is the Shannon’s entropy measure [61] and I ( . ) is the mutual information between the A and P . Davies Bouldin index (DB) : DB index is the ratio of the intracluster to intercluster distances. It is given as (8) D B = 1 k ∑ i = 1 k m a x j ≠ i ( i n t r a ( s i ) + i n t r a ( s j ) i n t e r ( x i , x j ) ) where, i n t r a ( s i ) = 1 n ∑ p a ∈ s i ( d ( p a , x i ) ) , is the intracluster distance formed by the cluster s i with x i as the cluster centroid and i n t e r ( x i , x j ) = d ( x i , x j ) , is the intercluster distance between the cluster centroids x i and x j . Lower values of DB index indicates better clustering. The minimum value of DB index is 0 . Edge density (ED): Edge density of a graph is the mean of edge densities of subgraphs obtained. (9) E D ( G ) = m e a n ( e d ( s i ) ) ∀ s i ∈ S G For e s i number of edges, | v s i | number of vertices and, | v s i | × ( | v s i | − 1 ) set of all possible edges in the subgraph s i , the e d ( s i ) = | e s i | | v s i | × ( | v s i | − 1 ) . The ED ranges from 0 to 1 . Higher value of ED denotes dense subgraph formation. Accuracy: Accuracy [64] is a measure of closeness of the predicted labels to the true labels, computed as: (10) A c c u r a c y = t p + t n t p + t n + f p + f n where t p is the number of true positives, t n is the number of true negatives, f p is the number of false positives and f n is the number of false negatives. The higher accuracy values imply that the predicted labels are closer to the true labels. Statistical tests Friedman test: This is a non-parametric statistical test which finds if the proposed clustering method or any of the state-of-the-art clustering techniques is better than that of the others [64]. It computes the chi-square test statistic as: (11) χ F 2 = 12 × | W L | u ( u + 1 ) [ ∑ j = 1 u R j 2 − u ( u + 1 ) 2 4 ] where | W L | is the number of different subsequence length used, u is the number of different clustering method used for evaluation and the average rank R j = 1 | W L | ∑ i = 1 | W L | r i j where r i j is rank of j th clustering technique for the i th WL. According to the null hypothesis, all the clustering techniques have the same performance if the p -value obtained from the corresponding χ F 2 is no less than the assumed significance level. On rejection of null hypothesis of Friedman test, we proceed with post hoc Nemenyi test. The test considers that the performance of proposed method is significantly different from the other state-of-the-art clustering methods if, | R 1 − R j | > α / 2 × u ( u + 1 ) / ( 6 × | W L | ) , where α is the significance level [64], R 1 is the rank of proposed clustering and { R j } j = 1 u − 1 is the rank of other methods. The p-values for the above statistical test is obtained, which if less than α , denote that the proposed method significantly differ from the compared method [65]. Wilcoxon signed rank test: This is non-parametric test that finds if there exists a significance difference between the paired values [66]. According to the null hypothesis H 0 : no significant difference exist because, the median of differences is zero and the alternate hypothesis H 1 : the median of differences is positive at α = 0 . 05 . The test statistic for n paired samples is W = m i n ( W + , W − ) . The W + is the sum of positive ranks, given as W + = ∑ ∀ i ∈ n r i , where r i is the rank assigned to i th pair which has positive difference value and W − is the sum of negative ranks, given as W − = ∑ ∀ j ∈ n r j , where r j is the rank assigned to j th pair which has negative difference value. The hypothesis H 0 is rejected if W ≤ W c r i t , where W c r i t is the critical value of W obtained from the critical value table. 5.4 Comparative methods Because this paper proposes a graph based clustering technique, we choose to compare it with the commonly used existing graph clustering algorithms as discussed below. 1. Fast greedy (FG): This is a greedy approach [67] in which the edges are added to a complete disconnected graph to form the communities and each time the modularity score is computed. This process continues till all the communities are merged, resulting in just one community. The cluster labels with highest modularity score is returned. 2. Minimum spanning tree based vertex betweenness: We obtain the minimum spanning tree (MST) of the given graph and the vertices are removed from MST in order of their betweenness score [68] and each time the modularity score is computed. The community formed from the cut vertex with highest modularity score is returned. 3. Girvan Newman edge betweenness (EB): The edge with highest edge betweenness score is removed from the given graph and the betweenness score is computed for the remaining edges. The process is repeated until no edge remains [69]. Cluster labels with the highest modularity score is returned. 4. Multilevel: At each iteration, the vertices are merged to form a community with maximum modularity score. The process is repeated until all the vertices find their communities or they form a community on its own [70]. 5. Infomap: This clustering creates the community structure by minimizing the description length of a random walk trajectory [71]. 6 Results and analysis In this section, we discuss the results corresponding to the experiments discussed in Section 5.2. 6.1 Planted quasi clique The experiments are performed on a time series dataset T with m = 30 different time series samples extracted randomly from the Ausgrid dataset. For illustrative purpose, we assume smaller length of time series, n = 80 and l = 8 . We obtain a graph representation from the time series dataset T , with | v | = 20 . The graph consists of the manually implanted maximal quasi cliques each of cluster size 5 . The graph vertices and the actual and predicted labels are shown in Table 2. We obtain the predicted labels using the proposed quasi-clique approach for ψ = { 0 . 2 , 0 . 25 } . The obtained NMI value 1 , indicate that the proposed quasi-clique successfully extracts the maximal quasi cliques for the given values of ψ . 6.2 Cluster quality In Table 3, we report the DB index and ED of the proposed clustering technique and other existing graph based clustering techniques- FG, MST-VB, EB, Multilevel and Infomap. In case of the proposed clustering technique, we report the lowest DB and highest ED, out of those obtained from varying WLs and ψ . While for the other graph based clustering approaches, we report the lowest DB and highest ED, out of those obtained from varying WLs. It is important to note that the proposed method shows a significant 15% and 38.7% improvement over the best performing baseline method EB when compared in terms of DB index of London and Ausgrid datasets respectively. The graph clustering techniques like FG and Multilevel decide the cluster labels based on the best modularity score, hence they are unable to capture the similarity between the vertices resulting to a higher DB index. Also the high ED values in FG, MST-VB, Multilevel and Infomap, signify that although they can form denser subgraphs but the similarity between the vertices is poor. The London dataset show highest ED of 0.99 because of the dense subgraphs obtained for ψ = 0 . 45 and WL = 2 h. Similarly, the Ausgrid dataset show highest ED of 1 for ψ = 0 . 75 and WL = 4 h. Although the DB index for WL 1 and 2 is lower in both the datasets, it shows a poor cluster distribution which leads to large number of clusters. The distribution of DB index and the ED values with changing ψ is depicted using boxplot in Fig. 4. To identify the best cluster set, we study the DB and ED values and also study the cluster distribution. For both the London and Ausgrid datasets, WL 6 show higher DB index. The DB index for WL 4 and 12 in case of London dataset, is similar and both of them show similar results. However the maximum DB index in case of WL 12 is less than that of WL 4 . Based on this study, we obtain WL 12 and ψ = 0 . 5 as the best cluster distribution and best graph representation for London dataset. In case of Ausgrid dataset in Fig. 4, the WLs 2 , 6 , 8 show higher DB index but WL 4 show lower DB index. Based on the DB index and cluster distribution, WL 4 and ψ = 0 . 65 is the best cluster set and best graph representation for the Ausgrid dataset. The Friedman χ 2 = 16 . 5 , p -value = 0.005 for the DB index and Friedman χ 2 = 26 . 837 , p -value = 6 . 137 e − 05 for the ED in case of London dataset. Therefore both the p-values show significant difference at p < 0 . 01 , rejecting the null hypothesis. Therefore, we proceed with the post-hoc Nemenyi test, and obtain the pair of clustering methods that differ significantly. In Table 3, we report the p-values obtained from post-hoc Nemenyi test. For the London dataset, the DB index of Multilevel clustering show p -value = 0 . 02 (p < 0.05). FG, MST-VB and Multilevel clustering differ significantly from the proposed method in terms of ED with p -value of 0.001, 0.0002 and 0.007 respectively (p < 0.05). The Friedman χ 2 = 19 . 8 , p -value = 0.001 for the DB index and Friedman χ 2 = 19 . 3 , p -value = 0.001 for the ED in case of Ausgrid dataset. Therefore both the p-values show significant difference at p < 0 . 01 , rejecting the null hypothesis. In Table 3, we report the p-values obtained from post-hoc Nemenyi test for the Ausgrid dataset. The DB index of Multilevel and Infomap clustering show p-values 0.004 and 0.02 respectively (p < 0.05). FG, MST-VB, and EB clustering differ significantly from the proposed method in terms of ED with p -value of 0.001, 0.02 and 0.03 respectively (p < 0.05). As shown in Table 3, for London dataset, the proposed method perform better than Multilevel in terms of both DB index and ED, and better than FG and MST-VB in terms of ED. In case of Ausgrid, the proposed method perform better than Multilevel and Infomap in terms of DB index and better than FG, MST-VB and EB in terms of ED. 6.3 Cluster characterization In this section we characterize the clusters obtained using the proposed method for each data set. 1. The stability score measured using entropy of each building is computed using Eq. (6). 1. London: In Fig. 10(a) we plot the entropy values of the buildings against the number of clusters per building. The right and top axes of Fig. 10(a) shows the distribution of the entropy and number of clusters per building in the London dataset. While the second distribution shows a peak around the mean, the entropy shows a positively skewed distribution with mean as 1.519 and median as 1.495. The mean entropy and mean number of clusters partition the plot into four regions, where all the building have: (A) below average entropy and below average number of clusters per building, (B) above average entropy and below average number of clusters per building, (C) above average entropy and above average number of clusters per building and (D) below average entropy and above average number of clusters per building. Though the choice of how much stability the utilities need is application and data dependent, the regions A, D and C are of particular interest. The regions A and D may be considered as a safe choice for stability as they denote the region where the successively occurring subsequences have fewer or infrequent changes in patterns. On the contrary, the region C may be considered as volatile region where the successively occurring subsequences frequently change their patterns. It is observed that in the London dataset nearly 46% buildings belong to region A while 22% buildings belong to the region C. Further, considering all entropy values greater than equal to 1 as high, we choose to filter the buildings having lower than 1 entropy and below average number of clusters per building as stable. In such case, we observe that in the London data set only 8% buildings have entropy lower than 1 whereas 7% buildings can be labeled as stable. In Fig. 10(a) we have highlighted the buildings with globally minimum entropy (building # 137 ), with globally maximum entropy (building # 198 ) and with minimum entropy within region A (building # 181 ) and have studied their load patterns in further details. In Fig. 10(b) we report the consumption pattern for 10 days for the highlighted buildings with various stability. Building # 198 with highest entropy value of 2.70 in Fig. 10(a), depicts frequent change in patterns and mean values in temporally dependent subsequences. The subsequences of building # 198 is distributed over 13 different clusters. On the other hand, building # 137 with lowest entropy value of 0.32, depicts regular patterns during the 10 day period. The subsequences of building # 137 is distributed over 7 clusters and 96% of the total subsequences belong to cluster # 2 . Building # 181 belongs to region A with entropy value of 0.423 while the subsequences of building # 181 is distributed over only 4 clusters. In building # 181 it is observed that 92.3% of the subsequences belong to the cluster # 2 and remaining 7.2% belong to the cluster # 11 with only exception of two subsequences. It is also noticed that in building # 181 nearly 13% of time patterns belonging to clusters # 2 and # 11 occur in subsequent time steps. The majority of occurrences in a single cluster for building # 137 and # 181 signifies that the consumption patterns are stable and predictable in nature. 2. Ausgrid: Fig. 10(c) shows the entropy values of the buildings against the number of clusters per building and the density plots for entropy and number of clusters per building. It is observed that in the Ausgrid dataset nearly 46% buildings belong to region A and D while 20% buildings belong to the region C. Further, we observe that in the Ausgrid data set only 4% buildings have entropy less than 1 and below average number of clusters per building that are labeled as stable. In Fig. 10(d) we show the consumption pattern for 10 days for the buildings with globally minimum entropy (building # 145 ), with globally maximum entropy (building # 95 ) and with minimum entropy within region A (building # 14 ) that are highlighted in Fig. 10(c). As shown in Fig. 10(c), building # 95 shows highest entropy value of 2.25. Two highest peaks are observed upto day 6 , but the pattern shapes differ each day. On the other plot, building # 145 shows lowest entropy value of 0.61. The peaks are observed during the start and end of the day, except day 10 still shows some instability. 82% of the subsequences of building 145 belongs to cluster # 7 . Building # 14 belongs to region A with entropy value as 0.672 while the subsequences of building # 14 is distributed over only 3 clusters. Further, we found that over 84% of the subsequences of building # 14 belong to cluster # 7 and over 15% belong to cluster # 4 with nearly 24% of time subsequent occurrences of patterns belonging to clusters # 7 and # 4 is observed. The majority of occurrences of subsequences in a single cluster for building # 145 and # 14 signifies that the consumption patterns are stable and predictable in nature. 6.4.2 Peak detection 1. London: We next analyze how the peak detection of stable buildings can help in load shifting or reduction in the peak consumption. For simplicity, we choose top- 10 most stable buildings with entropy between 0 and 1 , denoted as SB. For a randomly chosen day of March 1 s t we analyze the evening peak hours where the DR time interval is [ p : q ] = 6 − 10 p.m. We find which of the buildings from SB have their peaks during the DR time interval. Fig. 11(a) shows the heatmap of load values of the buildings in SB for every hour during the DR time interval. As shown in the figure for all the buildings in SB the peaks occur during the DR time interval. Importantly, 5 buildings, # 75 , # 136 , # 137 , # 179 , # 181 show their peaks at the same time, during 7 p.m, as highlighted in Fig. 11(a). Therefore, all 5 buildings # 75 , # 136 , # 137 , # 179 , # 181 or any combination of these in SB may be opted for load shifting operations to reduce the peak at 7 p.m. Additionally, all the top- 10 stable buildings can be chosen to shift their load based on the supply threshold and order of stability. The study can be carried out for any chosen value of k and any DR interval. 2. Ausgrid: Assuming we choose top- 25 most stable buildings with entropy between 0 and 1 , denoted as SB and the DR time interval as [ p : q ] = 6 − 10 p.m during a randomly chosen day of July 1 s t , we find that 12 buildings have peak occurrences at the DR time interval. We show the heatmap of load consumption values during the chosen DR time interval in Fig. 11, with the time of peak occurrences highlighted. However, it is noticed that maximum two buildings from SB show simultaneous peaks during any particular hour of DR interval. Therefore, all top- 25 stable buildings can be chosen for shifting, based on the supply threshold and order of stability during the DR interval. 6.4.3 Atypical pattern identification 1. London: Fig. 12(a) shows some of the discovered atypical patterns when the assumed threshold value v d = 4 . All the symbols shown in the figure belong to single sized cluster with maximum degree of 3 . To highlight the uniqueness in the pattern, we have shown two subsequences before and after the occurrence of atypical pattern in Fig. 12(a). The first pattern in Fig. 12(a) with symbol jff is observed only once and it belongs to cluster # 33 , also depicted in the cluster centroid in Section 6.3. Symbol dfe show a constant consumption and is observed in 4 different buildings with majority occurrences at 12 noon. Hence the discovery signifies that those buildings have minimal consumption during 12 noon. We perform the Wilcoxon signed rank test for n = 30 and the significance level α = 0 . 05 . From the critical value table, W c r i t ( n , α ) = 137 . The test statistic W obtained is 19 which is significantly less than the W c r i t and therefore we obtain a significant evidence that the frequency of occurrences of the atypical patterns is different from the frequency of occurrence of any randomly chosen normal pattern. Hence hypothesis H 0 is rejected in favor of H 1 . The p -value obtained is 9 . 3 e − 10 . 2. Ausgrid: Fig. 12(b) show the discovered atypical patterns when the assumed threshold value v d = 8 . To highlight the uniqueness in the pattern, we have shown two subsequences before and after the occurrence of the atypical pattern. Cluster # 8 has a vertex dae, with the lowest degree 6 . Cluster # 6 has vertex dee with degree 7 . We observe that dae occur in three different buildings in the entire dataset. The atypical pattern dee show 8 occurrences and majority of the occurrences is observed at 4 a.m. The peak towards the end of the pattern in case of d e e signify the occurrence of the atypical pattern during the early morning hours. Since only two atypical patterns are detected from the Ausgrid dataset, we choose a smaller value of n = 20 , for the Wilcoxon signed rank test. The significance level chosen is α = 0 . 05 . From the critical value table, W c r i t ( n , α ) = 51 . The test statistic W obtained is 1 which is significantly less than the W c r i t and therefore we obtain a significant evidence that the frequency of occurrences of the atypical patterns is different from the frequency of occurrence of normal patterns. Hence hypothesis H 0 is rejected in favor of H 1 . The p -value obtained is 9 . 5 e − 7 . 6.4.4 Case study on labeled data The CER-IRISH dataset consists of half-hourly load consumption of the buildings occupied by residential households, during the year 2009–2010 [72] which is divided into two periods — the benchmark period (July 2009–Dec 2009) and the test period (Jan 2010–Dec 2010). 3 3 https://www.cru.ie/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/cer11080ai.pdf. Fig. 13 shows half hourly load data for three randomly chosen CER-IRISH buildings during the first 5 days of the test period. The Irish electricity divided the buildings into test and control groups. During the benchmark period, all the buildings followed their usual load consumption regime without any DSM plans. During the test period, buildings in the test group were asked to trial different time of use tariffs and DSM stimuli while the buildings of control group followed their usual consumption regime. To validate the proposed method on this labeled information, we consider the test and control groups of buildings as the true labels and predict the stable set of buildings suitable for DR program. We apply the proposed quasi-clique clustering approach with changing WLs to obtain the best cluster set using the cluster quality measures DB and ED discussed in Section 5.3. Best cluster quality is observed for WL = 1 h, ψ = 0 . 35 . We use the entropy discussed in Section 4.1 as the stability score to predict the buildings with highest k stability scores and compute the accuracy using Eq. (10). In Table 4, we report accuracy results for WL = 1 h where k varies from 10 to 35. For k = 25 , the predicted results successfully match with that of the true labels with accuracy of 0.76. The highest accuracy is achieved for the minimum k value of 30 . We compared the results with the k least stable buildings (last- k ) that identifies the building with maximum fluctuations as probable participants to DR programs. We divide the dataset into 4 groups and evaluate the change in the consumption of test period over that of the benchmark period. • Group 1: the actual buildings that belong to test group • Group 2: the actual buildings that belong to control group • Group 3: the predicted top-25 buildings • Group 4: the buildings that belong to both actual and predicted test group in top-25. In Fig. 14(a), we illustrate the average day wise load consumption in the 4 groups. According to the Irish electricity, 5:00-7:00 p.m is considered as the peak time during which the DR operations are active. 4 4 https://www.cru.ie/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/cer11080ai.pdf. As shown in Fig. 14(a), Group 1 show a decrease in peak hour consumption, Group 2 do not show any significant decrease in the consumption during the peak hours of the test period. A significant decrease in consumption during the peak hours of test period is observed for Group 3 and 4. The percentage of change during the average daywise consumption of the predicted top-25 buildings, is illustrated in Fig. 14(b) which shows a gradual decrease of up to 25% during 5 p.m and then a gradual increase when moving away from the peak hours. Analysis on aggregate data: To study the stability of the residential buildings over the longer time period, we obtain the aggregate load values from the time series dataset T . Two different aggregation is obtained. 1. Daily aggregate: The daily aggregate is the sum of the daily loads ∀ t i ∈ T . 2. Weekly aggregate: The weekly aggregate is the sum of the weekly loads ∀ t i ∈ T . For daily aggregate, we obtain the clusters of subsequences for WL = { 2 , 4 , 8 , 12 , 16 , 24 , 48 } days. The maximum accuracy achieved for daily aggregate is 0.82 for the top-35 buildings, shown in Table 4. For the weekly aggregate, we obtain the clusters of subsequences for WL = { 2 , 4 , 8 , 12 } weeks. The maximum accuracy achieved for the weekly aggregate is 0.82 for both top-30 and top-35 buildings, shown in Table 4. The lower accuracy values in case of the last- k for both the daily and weekly aggregate, signify the validity of the proposed method. The top- k accuracy results for the aggregate data are similar to that of the hourly data, therefore instead of choosing the larger values of WLs, the proposed clustering can be applied on the aggregate data to study the DR programs for the longer time period. 7 Conclusions and future work Subsequence mining is a crucial task in building energy management system having potential to extract important knowledge about the load consumption patterns. Motivated by the success of the advanced graph theoretic approaches in extracting temporally dependent events, we formulate the subsequence clustering on residential building load data as a graph clustering problem on a weighted directed graph that can capture the temporal dependency as well as the similarity between the subsequences. We developed a novel quasi-clique based graph clustering algorithm to extract the temporally dependent similar subsequences that form cohesive mesoscopic structures. The comparative study of the clustering approach performed on London and Ausgrid datasets in Table 3 show 15% and 38.7% improvement respectively, than that of the best performing out of the existing methods, in terms of the DB index. The Friedman test and the post hoc Nemenyi test establish that the proposed clustering technique is better than majority of the other clustering techniques. The qualitative analysis of the patterns obtained from the cluster centroids reveal various consumption profiles and their time of occurrences. The atypical consumption patterns are obtained using a graph degree based analysis and it showcases the potential of the graph measure. The Wilcoxon signed rank test show significant difference in the frequency of occurrences of the atypical patterns and any randomly chosen pattern. The peak identification filters the buildings in which the peak belongs to a certain time interval and the building that are most stable. The experiments performed on a labeled dataset to identify the DR candidates on hourly basis achieve 0.83 accuracy for the minimum value of k = 30 stable buildings while the comparison with the last-35 unstable buildings manage to achieve an accuracy of only 0.30. A 25% decrease in electricity consumption during the peak hours is obtained due to the change in consumption pattern of the identified stable set of buildings. Following the design objectives of the study, the stable buildings identified that follow consistent load patterns are likely to participate in DR programs through long term contractual agreement for persistent peak load shifting and reduced daily energy consumption by adjusting their behavior pattern. Though it is undeniable that the buildings showing drastic change in consumption pattern might have the potential to match the sudden unpredictable supplies, their participation in the DR programs is considered as rather unreliable because of the expressed uncertainties. Such buildings, through voluntary program agreement or dynamic pricing, may be included in the DR programs focusing to balance uncertain demand and supply. Depending on the nature of stability the utility provider is interested in, the developed method can be used to identify the relevant buildings. The study can help the utility providers to offer flexibility in the energy system, help balance the supply demand relationship under generation uncertainty caused due to RE integration that in turn will reduce green house gas (GHG) emission. The study can also be used for better forecasting, planning and management of a smart energy system. In future, the graph based representation can be extended on streaming load data. The additional features representation like, time of peak occurrence can be used that will reveal additional insights like the peak occurrence time of the stable set of buildings. In order to study the appliance specific cluster shapes, the proposed subsequence clustering approach can be extended on multilayer graph where each layer correspond to an electric appliance. In regard to atypical pattern analysis, many other graph based measures can be used namely the Eigen vector centrality that considers the importance of a node with respect to its neighbors. The DR programs can be extended to discover the stable buildings in case of time series with long term seasonal variations. coredata.dc:description: The study of load consumption patterns through subsequence mining is a crucial task in smart cities and buildings as it extracts knowledge to assist in energy planning and management. The existing clustering based solutions do not capture the temporal dependency between the subsequences. Clustering temporally dependent similar subsequences can uncover key insight in a wide range of applications including demand response programs. In this work, we formulate the subsequence clustering on residential building load data as a graph clustering problem on a weighted directed graph. The weighted directed graph structure helps to capture the temporal dependency as well as the similarity between the subsequences. We propose a novel quasi-clique based graph clustering algorithm. No prior information about the number of clusters is required. The comparative study performed on residential building load dataset shows more than 15% improvement over the existing methods. The qualitative analysis of the distinctive patterns obtained from cluster centroids justifies a meaningful cluster set discovery. The labeled subsequences obtained through clustering helps to identify the successively occurring and atypical patterns, measure the stability of consumers that can rank the consumers for their suitability in demand response programs (DR) and load shifting operations.
coredata.dc:title: Load profile mining using directed weighted graphs with application towards demand response management
